questions.question: Which of the following set of quantities have members which are all vectors?
questions.explanation: Force, displacement, and momentum all require both magnitude and direction.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: If the relative humidity of the atmosphere increases, the rate of evaporation of sweat from the human body
questions.explanation: High relative humidity means the air is already saturated with water vapor, which significantly slows down the evaporation process.

questions.instruction: Identify the factor that doesn't determine resistance.
questions.question: Which of the following factors is not among those that determine the resistance of a wire?
questions.explanation: Resistance R = ρL/A. It depends on resistivity (material), length, and cross-sectional area. Mass is not a direct determining factor.

questions.instruction: Identify the scientist.
questions.question: Which of the following scientists suggested that moving particles exhibit wave properties?
questions.explanation: Louis de Broglie proposed the hypothesis of matter waves, stating that particles like electrons have an associated wavelength.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option from the following.
questions.question: In collision between two objects, kinetic energy is conserved only if

options.label: A
options.text: one of the objects was initially at rest

options.label: B
options.text: potential energy is converted to work

questions.explanation: In an elastic collision, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. In inelastic collisions, momentum is conserved but kinetic energy is not.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The quantity of motion of a body is its
questions.explanation: Linear momentum is defined as the product of mass and velocity (mv), and it represents the 'quantity of motion' possessed by a body.

questions.instruction: Identify the law described.
questions.question: The volume of a fixed mass of a gas varies inversely as the pressure on it provided the temperature is constant. This statement is
questions.explanation: Boyle's law states that for a fixed mass of gas at constant temperature, P₁V₁ = P₂V₂ (Pressure is inversely proportional to Volume).

questions.instruction: Select the correct property.
questions.question: An image formed on a screen is always
questions.explanation: Only real images can be formed on a screen, and real images are always inverted with respect to the object.

questions.instruction: Select the correct effect.
questions.question: How would the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor be affected if the distance of separation of its plates is decreased? It will
questions.explanation: The capacitance (C) of a parallel plate capacitor is given by C = εA/d. Since C is inversely proportional to distance (d), decreasing the distance increases the capacitance.

questions.instruction: Identify the machine that is the exception.
questions.question: Which of the following machines does not apply the lever principle?
questions.explanation: While a single pulley can be thought of as a modified lever, in standard machine classification, the claw hammer (1st class), wheelbarrow (2nd class), and sugar tong (3rd class) are direct applications of the lever principle. A single pulley is generally categorized separately as a pulley system.

questions.instruction: Select the correct term.
questions.question: The average distance moved by a molecule between collisions is called
questions.explanation: In kinetic theory, the mean free path is the average distance traveled by a moving particle (such as an atom or molecule) between successive collisions.

questions.instruction: Identify the wave type.
questions.question: Which of the following waves requires a material medium for its propagation?
questions.explanation: Sound waves are mechanical waves and require a medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel. Radio waves, light, and X-rays are electromagnetic waves and can travel through a vacuum.

questions.instruction: Select the correct chemical.
questions.question: The depolarising agent in a Leclanché cell is
questions.explanation: Manganese (IV) oxide (MnO₂) acts as the depolarizer in a Leclanché cell by oxidizing hydrogen gas to water, preventing it from bubbling up and polarizing the carbon electrode.

questions.instruction: Select the correct material.
questions.question: The material used to slow down the neutrons in a nuclear reactor is
questions.explanation: A moderator (like graphite or heavy water) is used in a nuclear reactor to slow down fast-moving neutrons to thermal speeds so that they can effectively cause further fission.

questions.instruction: Identify the reason.
questions.question: Which of the following statements explains why hot soapy water is more effective in cleaning oil-stained dishes?

options.label: A
options.text: The oil on the dishes repels the soap

options.label: B
options.text: Soap and heat decrease the surface tension of oil

options.label: C
options.text: Soap increases the surface tension of oil and water

options.label: D
options.text: Hot water increases the surface tension of oil

questions.explanation: Surface tension prevents water from wetting surfaces well. Adding soap and increasing temperature both decrease surface tension, allowing the water to mix with and lift the oil.

questions.instruction: Refer to the diagram of the reflecting prism.
questions.question: The diagram illustrates a beam of parallel rays from a distant object O, incident on one side of the total reflecting prism. Which diagram does not represent the correct path of the beam when it emerges from the prism?
questions.explanation: In total internal reflection within a 45-degree prism, rays should turn exactly 90 or 180 degrees. Diagram X likely shows an incorrect refraction or angle that contradicts the law of reflection at the hypotenuse.

questions.instruction: Identify the type of device.
questions.question: An electrical device has 50 turns in its primary coil and 20 turns in the secondary coil. The device can be a/an
questions.explanation: A transformer where the number of secondary turns (Ns) is less than the primary turns (Np) is a step-down transformer (Ns < Np).

questions.instruction: Select the correct energy conversion.
questions.question: The earpiece of a telephone handset converts energy from
questions.explanation: The earpiece acts as a speaker; it receives electrical signals and converts them into vibrations that produce sound waves.

questions.instruction: Identify the correct graph of temperature vs time.
questions.question: Two identical cups containing the same volume of water at 45°C and 5°C are left in a room at 25°C. Which of the following graphs correctly illustrates the variation of temperature with time?
questions.explanation: According to Newton's Law of Cooling, the temperature of an object asymptotically approaches the room temperature. The 45°C water will cool down towards 25°C, and the 5°C water will warm up towards 25°C.

questions.instruction: Calculate the angle of refraction.
questions.question: A ray of light traveling from glass into ethyl alcohol is incident at the boundary at an angle of incidence 30°. Calculate the angle of refraction. [Refractive index of glass = 1.5; refractive index of ethyl alcohol = 1.36]
questions.explanation: Using Snell's law: n₁sinθ₁ = n₂sinθ₂. (1.5)sin(30°) = (1.36)sin(r). 0.75 = 1.36 * sin(r). sin(r) = 0.551. r = sin⁻¹(0.551) ≈ 33.5°.

questions.instruction: Solve for the apparent weight.
questions.question: A 60 kg man stands on a weighing balance in an elevator. If the elevator accelerates upwards at 5 m/s², determine the reading of the scale. [g = 10 m/s²]
questions.explanation: For upward acceleration, apparent weight R = m(g + a). R = 60(10 + 5) = 60 * 15 = 900 N.

questions.instruction: Calculate the final temperature.
questions.question: The length of an iron bar is 100 cm at 20°C. At what temperature will its length increase by 0.01%? [Linear expansivity of iron = 1.2 × 10⁻⁵ °C⁻¹]

questions.instruction: Solve for the galvanometer resistance.
questions.question: A moving-coil galvanometer which gives a full-scale deflection with 0.005 A is converted to a voltmeter reading up to 5 V using an external resistance of 975 Ω. What is the resistance of the meter?

questions.instruction: Predict behavior in a magnetic field.
questions.question: A beam consisting of α-particles, β-particles and γ-rays passes through a magnetic field at right angles to the direction of the field. Which of the following observations would be made about the α, β, and γ respectively?
questions.explanation: Alpha (+) and Beta (-) particles are charged and will be deflected in opposite directions by a magnetic field. Gamma rays are neutral electromagnetic radiation and are not deflected.

questions.instruction: Analyze changes in the capacitor.
questions.question: A parallel plate capacitor is charged and the charging battery is subsequently disconnected. If the plates of the capacitor are moved farther apart by means of insulating handles, the

options.label: C
options.text: charge on the capacitor would increase

options.label: D
options.text: charge on the capacitor would decrease

questions.explanation: If the battery is disconnected, the charge (Q) remains constant. Since C = εA/d, increasing the distance (d) decreases the capacitance.

questions.instruction: Calculate speed of sound at a higher temperature.
questions.question: The velocity of sound in air at 15°C is 340 m/s. Calculate the velocity at 47°C.
questions.explanation: v ∝ √T (where T is in Kelvin). v₁/v₂ = √(T₁/T₂). 340/v₂ = √(288/320). 340/v₂ ≈ 0.948. v₂ ≈ 358 m/s.

questions.instruction: Identify the Ohmic graph.
questions.question: Which of the current-voltage characteristics shown above is that exhibited by an ohmic conductor?
questions.explanation: An Ohmic conductor follows Ohm's law (V=IR), meaning the V-I graph is a straight line passing through the origin.

questions.instruction: Calculate work done against friction.
questions.question: A 500 N box rests on a horizontal floor. A constant horizontal force is exerted on the box so that it moves through 8 m. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the floor and the box is 0.22, calculate the work done on the box.
questions.explanation: Work done against friction = Friction force * distance. Friction = μ * Normal Force = 0.22 * 500 = 110 N. Work = 110 * 8 = 880 J.

questions.instruction: Refer to the diagram of the ball on an inclined plank.
questions.question: The normal force on the ball is
questions.explanation: The component of the weight acting perpendicular to the inclined plane (the normal force) is mg cos θ.

questions.instruction: Based on the inclined plank diagram.
questions.question: The net force on the ball along the plank is
questions.explanation: The component of weight pulling the ball down the plank is mg sin θ. The kinetic friction F opposes the motion. Net force = mg sin θ - F.

questions.instruction: Identify the factors.
questions.question: What factors determine the frequency of a note emitted by a vibrating string?

options.label: A
options.text: Amplitude of vibration, force constant of string and length of string

options.label: B
options.text: Amplitude of vibration, force constant of string, and tension in string

options.label: C
options.text: Mass per unit length of string, tension in string and length of string

options.label: D
options.text: Force constant of string, tension in string, and length of string

questions.explanation: The frequency of a vibrating string is given by f = (1/2L)√(T/μ), where L is length, T is tension, and μ is mass per unit length.

questions.instruction: Solve for the electric force.
questions.question: The magnitude of the force experienced by a charge of 1.6 × 10⁻⁸ C in a uniform electric field of intensity 5 × 10⁵ N/C is

questions.instruction: Identify the false statement about viscosity.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about viscosity is not true? It

options.label: A
options.text: depends on areas of the surfaces in contact

options.label: C
options.text: is independent of the relative velocity of the layers

options.label: D
options.text: depends on the tangential force between the layers

questions.explanation: Viscosity represents internal friction in a fluid; the viscous force *is* dependent on the relative velocity of the layers (velocity gradient).

questions.instruction: Calculate acceleration.
questions.question: A motorcycle starting from rest is uniformly accelerated such that its velocity in 10 s is 72 km/h. What is its acceleration?

questions.instruction: Convert the temperature interval.
questions.question: The temperature of an object is raised by 120°C. The resulting increase in its absolute temperature is
questions.explanation: A temperature difference (increase) of 1 degree Celsius is exactly equal to a temperature difference of 1 Kelvin.

questions.instruction: Identify the true statement.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the motion of a simple pendulum is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a simple harmonic motion when the angle of displacement is large

options.label: B
options.text: It passes the equilibrium position with minimum speed

options.label: C
options.text: It possesses maximum kinetic energy at the extreme positions

options.label: D
options.text: It swings faster at the poles than at the equator

questions.explanation: Gravity (g) is slightly stronger at the poles. Since T = 2π√(L/g), a higher 'g' means a smaller period 'T', meaning the pendulum swings faster.

questions.instruction: Select the correct expression for the period.
questions.question: An electron of mass m and charge e moves in a circular path in a magnetic field of flux density B. How long does it take to complete one orbit?
questions.explanation: Bqv = mv²/r -> r/v = m/Bq. Period T = 2πr/v = 2πm/Be (where e is the charge q).

questions.instruction: Identify the correct observation about photoelectrons.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about photoelectrons is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A faint green light produces photoelectrons with less kinetic energy than a bright red light

options.label: B
options.text: A red light releases a smaller number of electrons than a green light

options.label: C
options.text: A faint green light produces photoelectrons with greater kinetic energy than a bright red light

options.label: D
options.text: A red light produces more photoelectrons than a green light

questions.explanation: The kinetic energy of photoelectrons depends on the frequency of incident light. Green light has a higher frequency than red light, so its photoelectrons have more energy, regardless of intensity (brightness).

questions.instruction: Calculate latent heat from the heating curve.
questions.question: The sketched graph above illustrates the heating curve of 0.02 kg of water. Determine the approximate value of the specific latent heat of vaporization of water.
questions.explanation: Specific latent heat of vaporization of water is a constant approximately equal to 2.26 × 10⁶ J/kg. This value is used to calculate the energy required to boil water at 100°C.

questions.instruction: Identify the relationship in a hydraulic press.
questions.question: In the hydraulic press, the force F applied is related to the diameter d of the cylinder by
questions.explanation: Force F = Pressure * Area. Since Area = πd²/4, Force is directly proportional to the square of the diameter (d²).

questions.instruction: Calculate the impedance.
questions.question: In an electric circuit, an inductor of inductance 0.5 H and resistance 50 Ω is connected to an alternating current source of frequency 60 Hz. Calculate the impedance of the circuit.

questions.instruction: Identify the correct explanation.
questions.question: Which of the following statements correctly explains why a total solar eclipse would be seen by people on only a small portion of the earth's surface?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon is larger in diameter than the earth

options.label: B
options.text: The earth is larger in diameter than the sun

options.label: C
options.text: The earth revolves around the sun

options.label: D
options.text: The earth is larger in diameter than the moon

questions.explanation: Because the Moon is much smaller than the Earth, its shadow (the umbra) during a solar eclipse only covers a small path on the Earth's surface at any given time.

questions.instruction: Calculate the speed in shallow water.
questions.question: Water waves have a wavelength of 3.6 cm and speed of 18 cm/s in deep water. If the waves enter shallow water with wavelength of 2.0 cm, calculate the speed of the waves in the shallow water.
questions.explanation: Frequency f is constant. f = v₁/λ₁ = v₂/λ₂. 18/3.6 = v₂/2.0. 5 = v₂/2.0. v₂ = 10.0 cm/s.

questions.instruction: Identify the required modification.
questions.question: An a.c. generator can be converted to a d.c. electric motor by replacing the

options.label: A
options.text: slip rings with a split ring and connecting a battery

options.label: B
options.text: split ring with slip rings and connecting a battery

options.label: C
options.text: a.c. with d.c. source and connecting slip rings

options.label: D
options.text: a.c. with d.c. source and connecting split rings

questions.explanation: Slip rings produce AC. A split ring (commutator) allows for DC operation. To make it a motor, an external energy source (battery) must be connected.

questions.instruction: Identify the true statement about refraction.
questions.question: A ray of light travels obliquely from a less dense medium to a denser medium. Which of the following statements is true about the light?

options.label: A
options.text: The wavelength of the light increases in the second medium

options.label: B
options.text: The speed of the light increases in the second medium

options.label: C
options.text: The light refracts towards the normal

options.label: D
options.text: There is a change in the frequency of the light

questions.explanation: When light enters a denser medium, it slows down and its path bends towards the normal.

questions.instruction: Calculate the De Broglie wavelength.
questions.question: An electron of mass 9.1 × 10⁻³¹ kg is travelling at a speed of 2.0 × 10⁶ m/s. Calculate the associated wavelength of the electron. [h = 6.6 × 10⁻³⁴ Js]

questions.instruction: Identify true statements about melting.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the process of melting of a solid are true? I. temperature remain steady until melting starts II. keep rising until melting starts III. remain steady as melting proceeds IV. keep rising as melting proceeds
questions.explanation: As a solid is heated, its temperature rises until it reaches its melting point (II). During the phase change (melting), the temperature remains constant until all the solid has turned to liquid (III).

questions.instruction: Analyze the energy change.
questions.question: A diver steps off a diving platform that is 10 m above the water. If there is no air resistance during the fall, there will be a decrease in the diver's
questions.explanation: As the diver falls, height decreases, resulting in a decrease in gravitational potential energy (mgh). This energy is converted into kinetic energy.

questions.instruction: Identify how to increase the force.
questions.question: Which of the following actions would increase the electric force between two positively charged particles?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreasing the mass of the particles

options.label: B
options.text: Decreasing the distance between the particles

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the distance between the particles

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the mass of the particles

questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states F = kq₁q₂/r². Because the force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance (r), decreasing the distance increases the force.

questions.instruction: Select the correct definition.
questions.question: A luminous object is one that

options.label: A
options.text: gives off dim blue-green light only in the dark

options.label: B
options.text: gives out light of its own

options.label: D
options.text: glows only in the presence of light

questions.explanation: A luminous object (like the Sun or a lit candle) generates and emits its own light, whereas non-luminous objects are only seen via reflected light.

questions.instruction: Identify the derived unit.
questions.question: Which of the following units is not fundamental?
questions.explanation: The Joule is a derived unit (kg·m²/s²). Metre, Kilogram, and Candela are part of the seven SI fundamental (base) units.

questions.instruction: Select the correct explanation for heat loss reduction.
questions.question: The vacuum between the double walls of a thermos flask reduces heat loss through
questions.explanation: Conduction and convection require a material medium (matter) to transfer heat. A vacuum eliminates this medium, effectively stopping heat transfer by these two methods.

questions.instruction: Identify the proportionality.
questions.question: In photoelectric effect, the number of electrons emitted per second from a metallic surface is proportional to the
questions.explanation: In the photoelectric effect, the rate of electron emission (photoelectric current) is directly proportional to the intensity (brightness) of the light, provided the frequency is above the threshold.

questions.instruction: Identify the parallel EMF rule.
questions.question: When two cells of negligible internal resistances and equal e.m.f. denoted by E₁ and E₂ are connected in parallel, combined e.m.f. E is given by
questions.explanation: When identical cells are connected in parallel, the total EMF of the combination is equal to the EMF of a single cell.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following gases could be collected by downward displacement of air?
questions.explanation: Downward displacement of air (upward delivery) is used to collect gases that are less dense than air. Hydrogen has a molecular mass of 2, which is significantly lighter than air (~29).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following substances has the lowest boiling point?
questions.explanation: Comparing the molecular substances, Tetrachloromethane (CCl₄) has a boiling point of approximately 76.7°C, while Ethanol is about 78°C and Water is 100°C. NaCl(aq) has a boiling point elevation higher than 100°C.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The branch of science that deals with the nature and properties of substances and how one substance can be converted to another is known as
questions.explanation: Chemistry is the scientific study of the properties and behavior of matter, specifically focusing on substances and their transformations.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The electron configuration 1s² 2s² 2pₓ² contravenes the
questions.explanation: Hund's rule states that every orbital in a subshell is singly occupied with one electron before any one orbital is doubly occupied. The configuration shows two electrons in 2pₓ while 2pᵧ and 2p_z remain empty, which violates this rule.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The oxidation number of Chromium in Na₂Cr₂O₇ is

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The most important ore of aluminium is
questions.explanation: Bauxite is the primary commercial ore used for the extraction of aluminium.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Bases normally

options.label: B
options.text: turn litmus paper from blue to red

options.label: C
options.text: turn litmus paper from red to blue

questions.explanation: It is a characteristic property of bases to turn red litmus paper blue.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The product formed when concentrated sodium chloride solution is electrolysed using carbon electrodes is
questions.explanation: During the electrolysis of concentrated NaCl (brine), Cl₂ is produced at the anode and H₂ at the cathode. The remaining Na⁺ and OH⁻ ions in the solution form Sodium hydroxide.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The product of the reaction between ethanol and excess acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ is
questions.explanation: Excess acidified potassium dichromate(VI) is a strong oxidizing agent that oxidizes ethanol (a primary alcohol) completely to ethanoic acid (CH₃COOH).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about ammonium salt is correct? It

options.label: A
options.text: dissolves in water to form solution of pH > 1

options.label: B
options.text: dissolves in water to form solution of pH < 7

questions.explanation: Ammonium salts are derived from a weak base (ammonia) and a strong acid. Upon hydrolysis in water, they produce an acidic solution with a pH less than 7.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Ethanedioic acid is an organic solid that can be purified by
questions.explanation: Crystallization is the standard method for purifying organic solids by dissolving them in a suitable solvent at high temperature and allowing them to precipitate as pure crystals upon cooling.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following functional groups is present in alkanoic acid?
questions.explanation: The carboxyl group (–COOH) is the functional group that defines alkanoic acids.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: In ethanol, the attractive forces between adjacent molecules are

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen bonding and Van der Waals’ forces

questions.explanation: Ethanol molecules exhibit hydrogen bonding due to the –OH group and Van der Waals' forces due to the ethyl (C₂H₅) alkyl group.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: At 25°C, the saturated solution of a salt in water was found to contain 0.24 g of the salt in 100 cm³. What is the solubility of the salt in g dm⁻³?
questions.explanation: 100 cm³ contains 0.24 g. Since 1 dm³ = 1000 cm³, the solubility is 0.24 g * (1000/100) = 2.40 g dm⁻³.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The reaction represented by the equation: Ni²⁺(aq) + Fe(s) → Ni(s) + Fe²⁺(aq) is a redox reaction because

options.label: A
options.text: Ni²⁺ ions are oxidized and Fe acts as an oxidizing agent

options.label: B
options.text: Ni²⁺ ions are oxidized and Fe acts as a reducing agent

options.label: C
options.text: Ni²⁺ ions are reduced and Fe acts as an oxidizing agent

options.label: D
options.text: Ni²⁺ ions are reduced and Fe acts as a reducing agent

questions.explanation: Ni²⁺ gains electrons (is reduced) to become Ni(s). Fe(s) loses electrons (is oxidized) and thus acts as the reducing agent.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following statements describes transition elements? They
questions.explanation: Transition elements are characterized by having partially filled d-orbitals, which allows them to exhibit multiple (variable) oxidation states.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Aluminium is suitable for making alloys for aircraft construction because it

options.label: B
options.text: is light and very resistant to corrosion

options.label: C
options.text: has high density and is a non-conductor of electricity

questions.explanation: Aluminium's low density (lightweight) and ability to form a protective oxide layer (corrosion resistance) make it ideal for the aerospace industry.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following arrangements of elements is in order of increasing ionization energy?
questions.explanation: Ionization energy generally increases from left to right across a period. These elements belong to Period 3: Al (Group 13), Si (Group 14), P (Group 15), and S (Group 16). The correct increasing order is Al < Si < P < S.

questions.instruction: Consider the provided chemical equation.
questions.question: C₃H₈ + 5O₂ → 3CO₂ + 4H₂O. If 0.1 mole of C₃H₈ was completely burnt, what volume of CO₂ would be produced at STP? [Volume of gas at STP = 22.4 dm³ mol⁻¹]
questions.explanation: From the equation, 1 mole of propane produces 3 moles of CO₂. Thus, 0.1 mole propane produces 0.3 mole CO₂. Volume = 0.3 * 22.4 = 6.72 dm³.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Naturally occurring boron is made up of 19.9% ¹⁰B and 80.1% ¹¹B. The relative atomic mass of boron is

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The number of shared pairs of electrons in a molecule of methane is
questions.explanation: Methane (CH₄) consists of four single C-H covalent bonds. Each single bond represents one shared pair of electrons, totaling 4 pairs.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Isotopes of the same element have similar chemical properties because they have the same number of
questions.explanation: Chemical properties are determined by the electron configuration, which depends on the number of protons (atomic number) in a neutral atom. Isotopes have the same number of protons.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following household liquids would be effective in treating someone with too much acid in the stomach?
questions.explanation: Stomach acidity requires neutralization with a base. Milk of magnesia has a pH of 10.5, indicating it is an alkaline substance capable of neutralizing acid.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The percentage by mass of oxygen in MgSO₄·7H₂O is [Mr of MgSO₄·7H₂O = 246]
questions.explanation: There are 4 oxygen atoms in the sulfate and 7 in the water molecules, total 11 oxygen atoms. Mass = 11 * 16 = 176. % Oxygen = (176 / 246) * 100 ≈ 71.5%.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Catalysts alter reaction rates by

options.label: C
options.text: increasing the surface area of reactants

questions.explanation: Catalysts work by providing an alternative reaction mechanism that has a lower activation energy.

questions.instruction: Consider the provided equation for ethane combustion.
questions.question: 2C₂H₆(g) + 7O₂(g) → 6H₂O(g) + 4CO₂(g). Calculate the volume of steam that would be produced from 400 cm³ of ethane.
questions.explanation: According to Gay-Lussac's law of combining volumes, the ratio of C₂H₆ to H₂O is 2:6 or 1:3. Thus, 400 cm³ of ethane produces 400 * 3 = 1200 cm³ of steam.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: A saturated solution at 300°C will normally produce crystals at a temperature of
questions.explanation: Solubility generally decreases with decreasing temperature. To produce crystals, the solution must be cooled below its saturation temperature.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The following organic compounds are polymers except
questions.explanation: Rubber, starch, and proteins are natural polymers. Fats (lipids) are large biological molecules but are not composed of long chains of repeating monomer units in the same way polymers are.

questions.instruction: Select the condition NOT required.
questions.question: According to the collision theory of reaction rates, which of the following conditions is not required for two molecules to react? The molecules must

options.label: A
options.text: come into contact without loss of energy on colliding with each other

options.label: B
options.text: collide with enough energy to overcome the activation energy barrier

options.label: C
options.text: collide in an orientation that makes formation of product possible

options.label: D
options.text: possess enough speed to overcome intermolecular forces of attraction

questions.explanation: The requirement that collisions be elastic (no loss of energy) is an assumption for ideal gases, but it is not a requirement for a chemical reaction to occur.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: A weak acid is one which

options.label: C
options.text: does not produce salt with alkali

questions.explanation: The strength of an acid refers to its degree of ionization. Weak acids only partially (slightly) ionize in aqueous solution.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following conditions are necessary for the preparation of alkanoates from alkanols and alkanoic acid?
questions.explanation: Esterification (formation of alkanoates) involves the reaction of an alcohol with a carboxylic acid in the presence of a concentrated sulfuric acid catalyst and heat.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The volume of 22g of CO₂ at STP is equivalent to [C = 12, O = 16, molar volume at STP = 22.4 dm³]
questions.explanation: Molar mass of CO₂ = 44 g/mol. Moles = 22 / 44 = 0.5 mol. Volume = 0.5 * 22.4 = 11.2 dm³.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Pairs of outermost shell electrons which are not used in bonding are
questions.explanation: Lone pairs are pairs of valence electrons that are not involved in the formation of covalent bonds.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: ₈X²⁻ and ₁₀Y are
questions.explanation: Element X (Atomic number 8) as an ion X²⁻ has 8+2=10 electrons. Element Y (Atomic number 10) has 10 electrons. Since they have the same number of electrons, they are isoelectronic.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Pure water contaminated with quicklime will have a pH of
questions.explanation: Quicklime (CaO) reacts with water to form Calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)₂), which is an alkaline solution. Alkaline solutions have a pH greater than 7.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The electron configuration of ²⁹Cu is
questions.explanation: Copper is an exception to the Aufbau principle; an electron from the 4s subshell is promoted to the 3d subshell to achieve a more stable full d-subshell configuration.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: When s and p block elements react, the bond formed is
questions.explanation: Reactions between s-block metals (low electronegativity) and p-block non-metals (high electronegativity) typically result in the transfer of electrons, forming ionic (electrovalent) bonds.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The hardest form of carbon is
questions.explanation: In diamond, each carbon atom is tetrahedrally bonded to four others in a rigid 3D lattice, making it the hardest known natural substance.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The metallic bonding in aluminium is strong because of large number of
questions.explanation: Aluminium provides three valence electrons per atom to the sea of delocalized electrons, resulting in a stronger electrostatic attraction between the ions and the electron cloud compared to metals with fewer valence electrons.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: How many covalent bonds are formed by nitrogen?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen has 5 valence electrons and requires 3 more to complete its octet, thus it typically forms three covalent bonds.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: When an element exists in two or more forms in the same physical state, it exhibits
questions.explanation: Allotropy is the property of some chemical elements to exist in two or more different forms in the same physical state (e.g., diamond and graphite for carbon).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: An atom of an element in the ground state contains 8 valence electrons. The element is considered as a
questions.explanation: Noble gases (except Helium) have a full octet of 8 electrons in their outermost shell, making them very stable and unreactive.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The main function of limestone in the blast furnace during the extraction of iron is to
questions.explanation: Limestone (CaCO₃) decomposes to CaO, which reacts with silica (sand) impurities to form molten slag, which can be easily removed.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following is a monomer of polythene?
questions.explanation: Polythene (polyethylene) is formed by the polymerization of ethene monomers.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following compounds is formed by the oxidation of ethanol?
questions.explanation: Ethanol is oxidized to ethanal and further to ethanoic acid (CH₃CO₂H).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Tetraoxosulphate(VI) acid is considered as a heavy chemical because

options.label: A
options.text: its relative molecular mass is high

options.label: B
options.text: a high tonnage is produced every year

options.label: D
options.text: it is used to manufacture heavy chemicals

questions.explanation: In industrial chemistry, 'heavy chemicals' are those produced in very large quantities (tonnage) for use in various industrial processes.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: How many isomers can be formed from a compound with molecular formula C₅H₁₂?
questions.explanation: Pentane (C₅H₁₂) has three structural isomers: n-pentane, isopentane (2-methylbutane), and neopentane (2,2-dimethylpropane).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The oxidation number of iron in its free state is
questions.explanation: The oxidation number of any element in its free (uncombined) state is always 0.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Water pipes are produced from
questions.explanation: Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) is widely used in the manufacture of water pipes due to its durability, chemical resistance, and cost-effectiveness.

questions.instruction: Determine the coefficients for the balanced equation.
questions.question: Consider the reaction represented by the following equation: xAl + yCl₂ → zAlCl₃. The values of x, y, and z are respectively
questions.explanation: The balanced equation is 2Al + 3Cl₂ → 2AlCl₃. Thus x=2, y=3, and z=2.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following laws or theory cannot be explained by the application of the kinetic theory of gases?
questions.explanation: Kinetic theory of gases explains the macroscopic properties of gases (pressure, volume, temperature) based on molecular motion. Dalton's atomic theory deals with the nature and properties of atoms and chemical combinations, which is outside the scope of the kinetic molecular theory of gases.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The primary component of natural gas is
questions.explanation: Natural gas is a fossil fuel energy source primarily composed of methane (CH₄), usually making up 70–90% of the mixture.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Thermal cracking of alkanes usually
questions.explanation: Cracking is the process of breaking down (decomposing) large, complex hydrocarbon molecules into simpler, smaller ones like lower alkanes and alkenes using heat.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Carbon is deposited in the exhaust pipes of cars because of
questions.explanation: When there is insufficient oxygen during the combustion of fuel (petrol), incomplete combustion occurs, leading to the formation of carbon soot (unburnt carbon) and carbon monoxide.

questions.instruction: Calculate the moles based on Faraday's law.
questions.question: How many moles of copper would be deposited by passing 1 Faraday of electricity through a CuCl₂ solution?
questions.explanation: Copper in CuCl₂ is Cu²⁺. The reaction is Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu. This means 2 Faradays deposit 1 mole. Thus, 1 Faraday deposits 0.5 mole.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Alkenes can be manufactured by

options.label: A
options.text: Addition of hydrogen to unsaturated vegetable oils

questions.explanation: Cracking long-chain alkanes produces a mixture of smaller alkanes and alkenes (like ethene and propene), which are essential for the plastic industry.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Petrochemistry is an example of
questions.explanation: Applied chemistry involves the application of chemical principles and techniques to solve practical problems or produce useful products, such as in the processing of petroleum.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Species that occur in a reaction pathway but not in the overall reaction are known as
questions.explanation: Intermediates are substances formed in one elementary step of a multi-step reaction mechanism and consumed in a subsequent step, so they do not appear in the final balanced equation.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: An alkane with 49 carbon atoms contains 100 hydrogen atoms

options.label: B
options.text: Addition reactions occur between alkanes and chlorine

options.label: C
options.text: Butane has a lower boiling point than propane

questions.explanation: The general formula for alkanes is CₙH₂ₙ₊₂. If n = 49, H = (2 * 49) + 2 = 98 + 2 = 100. Alkanes undergo substitution, not addition. Pentane has 3 isomers.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The best indicator to use for the titration of ethanoic acid with sodium hydroxide is
questions.explanation: Ethanoic acid is a weak acid and sodium hydroxide is a strong base. The pH at the equivalence point will be greater than 7 (basic), making phenolphthalein (range 8.3–10) the most suitable indicator.

questions.instruction: Identify the half-equation.
questions.question: The reduction half-equation of Zn(s) + CuSO₄(aq) → ZnSO₄(aq) + Cu(s) is
questions.explanation: In this displacement reaction, Copper ions (Cu²⁺) gain two electrons to form neutral Copper atoms (Cu), which is the process of reduction.

questions.instruction: Calculate the solubility in mol dm⁻³.
questions.question: If 100 cm³ of a saturated solution of sodium tetraoxosulphate (VI) at 30°C contains 10.5 g of the salt, what would be its solubility at this temperature? [Na₂SO₄ = 142]
questions.explanation: 10.5g in 100cm³ = 105g in 1000cm³. Moles = 105 / 142 = 0.739. Solubility = 0.74 mol dm⁻³.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: An example of a crystalline substance that does not possess water of crystallization is
questions.explanation: Potassium trioxonitrate (V), KNO₃, exists as anhydrous crystals and does not have water of crystallization, unlike hydrated salts like Na₂CO₃.10H₂O or FeSO₄.7H₂O.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The salt solution formed from a reaction between ethanoic acid and sodium hydroxide would be
questions.explanation: Sodium ethanoate (the salt formed) is a salt of a weak acid and a strong base. It undergoes hydrolysis in water to produce hydroxide ions (OH⁻), making the solution basic.

questions.instruction: Select the hydrolysis reaction.
questions.question: Which of the following reactions represents the hydrolysis of an alkanoate?
questions.explanation: Hydrolysis of an ester (alkanoate) is the reaction with water to produce the parent carboxylic acid and alcohol. Option C correctly shows ethyl ethanoate reacting with water to form ethanoic acid and ethanol.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the collision theory is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Rate of reaction is proportional to the number of effective collisions

options.label: C
options.text: Collision of molecules will split the molecules

questions.explanation: According to collision theory, only effective collisions (those with sufficient energy and correct orientation) lead to a reaction. The higher the number of effective collisions, the faster the reaction rate.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Why are H₂SO₄ and CaCl₂ not suitable for drying ammonia gas? They
questions.explanation: Ammonia is a basic gas. It reacts with H₂SO₄ (acidic) to form ammonium sulphate and with CaCl₂ to form a complex compound [CaCl₂.8NH₃]. Therefore, they cannot be used as drying agents for it.

questions.instruction: Identify the incorrect equation.
questions.question: Which of the following equations does not correctly illustrate a reaction of chlorine?
questions.explanation: A halogen can only displace a less reactive halogen (one below it in the group) from its salt. Since Fluorine is more reactive than Chlorine, Chlorine cannot displace Fluorine from NaF.

questions.instruction: Determine the number of unpaired electrons.
questions.question: How many unpaired electrons are present in ²⁶Fe³⁺?
questions.explanation: Fe is [Ar] 3d⁶ 4s². Fe³⁺ loses 3 electrons (two from 4s, one from 3d) to become [Ar] 3d⁵. In the 3d subshell, all 5 electrons remain unpaired according to Hund's rule.

questions.instruction: Select the correct trend.
questions.question: Going down Group II in the periodic table normally
questions.explanation: As you move down a group, the number of electron shells increases, which increases the shielding effect. Atomic radius increases, leading to a decrease in ionization energy and electronegativity.

questions.instruction: Select the correct element.
questions.question: Which of the following elements has its valence electrons in the s-orbital?
questions.explanation: Sodium (Na) has atomic number 11. Its configuration is 1s² 2s² 2p⁶ 3s¹. Its valence electron is in the 3s orbital.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The periodic property used to determine whether a covalent molecule is polar or not is
questions.explanation: A bond is polar if there is a significant difference in electronegativity between the two bonded atoms, causing an unequal sharing of electrons.

questions.instruction: Identify the exception.
questions.question: The following steps are scientific methods except
questions.explanation: Scientific methods include steps like problem identification, hypothesis, experimentation, and analysis. Open-mindedness is a scientific *attitude* or trait, not a step in the procedural method.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Isoelectronic species have the same number of
questions.explanation: Isoelectronic refers to atoms, ions, or molecules that have the same number of electrons (e.g., Na⁺, Ne, and Mg²⁺ all have 10 electrons).

questions.instruction: Calculate the RAM.
questions.question: An element X has two isotopes, ⁶⁵X and ⁶⁶X with relative abundance of 60% and 40% respectively. The relative atomic mass of X is

questions.instruction: Select the pair.
questions.question: The pair of compounds that belongs to the same homologous series is
questions.explanation: C₂H₆ (Ethane) and C₄H₁₀ (Butane) both follow the general formula CₙH₂ₙ₊₂ for alkanes, making them members of the same homologous series.

questions.instruction: Select the consequence.
questions.question: A consequence of global warming is
questions.explanation: Global warming leads to the melting of polar ice caps and thermal expansion of seawater, which causes rising sea levels and flooding of coastal regions.

questions.instruction: Determine the lowest rate of diffusion.
questions.question: Which of the following gases has the lowest rate of diffusion? [H=1, C=12, N=14, O=16]
questions.explanation: According to Graham's law, the rate of diffusion is inversely proportional to the square root of the molar mass. Molar masses: N₂=28, NH₃=17, O₂=32, CH₄=16. Oxygen has the highest mass and thus the lowest rate.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The gas that is less dense than air is
questions.explanation: The average molar mass of air is approximately 29. Molar masses: CO₂=44, N₂=28, Cl₂=71, O₂=32. Nitrogen is the only one lighter than air.

questions.instruction: Select the highest conductivity.
questions.question: Which of the following equimolar solutions has the highest conductivity?
questions.explanation: Conductivity depends on the concentration of ions. H₂SO₄ is a strong acid that dissociates to give 3 ions per molecule (2H⁺ + SO₄²⁻), whereas NaOH gives 2 and H₂CO₃ is a weak acid.

questions.instruction: Select the correct process.
questions.question: What takes place at the cathode during electrolysis?
questions.explanation: At the cathode, reduction occurs. Positive ions (cations) move to the cathode, gain electrons, and are discharged.

questions.instruction: Calculate the mass required.
questions.question: How many grams of NaOH(s) would be needed to produce 100 cm³ of a 0.20 mol dm⁻³ NaOH(aq)? [NaOH = 40.0]
questions.explanation: Moles = Molarity * Volume(dm³) = 0.20 * (100 / 1000) = 0.02 mol. Mass = moles * molar mass = 0.02 * 40 = 0.80 g.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The formation of a bond between hydrogen and a highly electronegative atom results in
questions.explanation: A bond between hydrogen and a highly electronegative atom (like O, N, or F) is a polar covalent bond, creating a permanent dipole and resulting in molecular polarity.

questions.instruction: Select the non-polar bond.
questions.question: The molecule that has a non-polar covalent bond is
questions.explanation: In Cl₂, the two chlorine atoms have equal electronegativity, so the shared pair of electrons is shared equally, resulting in a non-polar bond.

questions.instruction: Study the data provided to answer the question.
questions.question:
Which of the elements in the table below would react more readily with chlorine?

ElementIonization energy (kJ mol⁻¹ × 10⁻³)
w12.0
x21.0
y106.0
z200.0
questions.explanation: Chlorine is a highly electronegative non-metal that reacts best with elements that have low ionization energies (elements that lose electrons easily). W and X have the lowest values in the table.

questions.instruction: Calculate vapour density.
questions.question: The relative molar mass of a gaseous hydrocarbon is 30. Determine its vapour density.
questions.explanation: Relative molar mass = 2 * vapour density. Therefore, vapour density = 30 / 2 = 15.

questions.instruction: Analyze the thermochemical equation.
questions.question: Consider the reaction: 2SO₃(g) → 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g), ΔH = +198 kJ mol⁻¹ Which of the following statements about the reaction is correct?

options.label: C
options.text: 198 kJ of energy is given off

questions.explanation: A positive ΔH indicates an endothermic reaction, meaning energy is absorbed from the surroundings during the process.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following properties does not give evidence of the kinetic theory of matter?
questions.explanation: Evaporation, diffusion, and melting are physical processes explained by molecular motion and spacing (Kinetic Theory). Polymerization is a chemical reaction where monomers combine to form polymers, which is not direct evidence for the kinetic theory.

questions.instruction: Select the compound.
questions.question: A compound that could be dried by using conc. tetraoxosulphate (VI) acid and not by calcium oxide is likely to be
questions.explanation: Concentrated H₂SO₄ is an acidic drying agent suitable for acidic gases (acid anhydrides). Calcium oxide is basic and would react with acid anhydrides, so it cannot dry them.

questions.instruction: Select the correct bond.
questions.question: Positive ions in a sea of electrons are found in
questions.explanation: Metallic bonding is the electrostatic attraction between metal cations (positive ions) and the surrounding sea of delocalized electrons.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Dilute trioxonitrate (V) acid does not produce hydrogen when it reacts with metals because

options.label: A
options.text: It is a strong oxidizing agent

questions.explanation: HNO₃ is a powerful oxidizing agent. It oxidizes the hydrogen gas produced to water and is itself reduced to nitrogen oxides.

questions.instruction: Calculate the number of moles.
questions.question: How many moles are there in 3.0 g of O₃? [O = 16]
questions.explanation: Molar mass of O₃ = 16 × 3 = 48. Moles = Mass / Molar Mass = 3.0 / 48 = 0.0625.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Copper (II) ions are able to participate in coordinate covalent bonding because they
questions.explanation: Transition metal ions like Cu²⁺ have vacant d-orbitals that can accept electron pairs from ligands to form coordinate (dative) bonds.

questions.instruction: Calculate volume.
questions.question: Determine the volume of 0.100 mol of HCl in 0.250 mol dm⁻³ solution.
questions.explanation: Volume(dm³) = moles / concentration = 0.100 / 0.250 = 0.4 dm³. To convert to cm³, 0.4 * 1000 = 400 cm³.

questions.instruction: Identify the incorrect statement.
questions.question: Which of the statements about gases is not correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The total kinetic energy of the gas is not affected by collision

options.label: B
options.text: Molecules of the gas are in constant motion

options.label: C
options.text: Gases have low densities compared to solids and liquids

options.label: D
options.text: Gases are highly soluble in water at high temperatures

questions.explanation: The solubility of most gases in water actually *decreases* as the temperature increases.

questions.instruction: Arrange in decreasing order of boiling points.
questions.question: Arrange the following compounds in decreasing order of their boiling points: NH₃, HF, SiH₄, CH₄
questions.explanation: HF and NH₃ have hydrogen bonding, with HF being stronger due to Fluorine's higher electronegativity. SiH₄ is heavier than CH₄, giving it stronger van der Waals forces. The order is HF > NH₃ > SiH₄ > CH₄.

questions.instruction: Identify the incorrect statement.
questions.question: The following statements are correct except

options.label: A
options.text: Energy is released when liquids change to solids

options.label: B
options.text: Particles move faster in the gaseous state than in the liquid state

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon atoms in gaseous methane are further apart than in solid diamond

options.label: D
options.text: There is large decrease in the volume of a solid metal when pressure is applied

questions.explanation: Solids are highly incompressible because their particles are already packed closely together. Applying pressure results in negligible volume decrease.

questions.instruction: Calculate the vapour density.
questions.question: The vapour density of an organic compound with molecular formula C₄H₄O₂ is [H=1, C=12, O=16]
questions.explanation: Molar mass = (12×4) + (1×4) + (16×2) = 48 + 4 + 32 = 84. Vapour Density = Molar Mass / 2 = 84 / 2 = 42.

questions.instruction: Select the technique.
questions.question: A mixture containing two salts of different solubility can be separated by
questions.explanation: Fractional crystallization is used to separate two dissolved substances based on their different solubilities at different temperatures.

questions.instruction: Select the technique.
questions.question: The separation technique suitable for separating iodine from tetrachloromethane is
questions.explanation: Since iodine is soluble in tetrachloromethane (forming a homogenous liquid mixture), they can be separated by fractional distillation based on the difference in their boiling points.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The by-product of fermentation of sugar is
questions.explanation: Fermentation of sugar (glucose) by yeast produces ethanol and carbon (IV) oxide as a by-product: C6H12O6 → 2C2H5OH + 2CO2.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following sugars is a product of the condensation of monosaccharides?
questions.explanation: Maltose is a disaccharide formed by the condensation of two glucose (monosaccharide) molecules.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The cleansing effect of soap is low in acidic water because of

options.label: a
options.text: The formation of unionized fatty acid

options.label: b
options.text: Increase in the PH of the soap molecules

options.label: d
options.text: The hardness of the acidic water

questions.explanation: In acidic water, H+ ions react with soap (sodium stearate) to form weak, unionized fatty acids (stearic acid), which precipitate out and reduce the soap's ability to emulsify oil.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: The following compounds are condensation polymers except
questions.explanation: Polyethene is an addition polymer formed from the monomer ethene. Nylon, proteins, and starch are formed by condensation polymerization.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: What amount of electricity is required to deposit one mole of aluminium from a solution of AlCl₃?
questions.explanation: Aluminium ions have a charge of +3 (Al³⁺). To deposit one mole of Al, three moles of electrons are required: Al³⁺ + 3e⁻ → Al. Therefore, 3 Faradays are needed.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Which of the following compounds would react rapidly with bromine?
questions.explanation: Hexene is an alkene containing a carbon-carbon double bond, which undergoes a rapid addition reaction with bromine (decolorizing it).

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
Alkanols can be manufactured from alkenes by the initial reaction of alkenes with
questions.question: Alkanols can be manufactured from alkenes by the initial reaction of alkenes with
questions.explanation: Alkenes react with concentrated H2SO4 to form alkyl hydrogen sulphates, which are then hydrolyzed with water to produce alkanols.

questions.instruction: Select the incorrect statement.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about the standard hydrogen electrode is not correct?

options.label: a
options.text: The hydrogen gas is at a pressure of 1 atmosphere

options.label: b
options.text: A solution containing 1 mol dm⁻³ of H⁺(aq) ions is used

questions.explanation: Standard conditions for a hydrogen electrode require a temperature of 25°C (298 K), not 20°C.

questions.instruction: Calculate the empirical formula.
questions.question: If 60g of M combines with 24g of oxygen, what would the empirical formula of the oxide be? [O = 16.0, M = 120]
questions.explanation: Moles of M = 60/120 = 0.5. Moles of O = 24/16 = 1.5. Mole ratio M:O = 0.5:1.5 = 1:3. Empirical formula is MO3.

questions.instruction: Choose the correct products for the electrodes.
questions.question:
The products of the electrolysis of dilute sodium chloride using carbon electrodes are:
AnodeCathode
(a)ChlorineSodium
(b)OxygenHydrogen
(c)ChlorineHydrogen
(d)HydrogenOxygen
questions.explanation: In dilute NaCl, OH⁻ ions are discharged at the anode to produce Oxygen, and H⁺ ions are discharged at the cathode to produce Hydrogen.

questions.instruction: Calculate the quantity of electricity.
questions.question: Determine the quantity of electricity used when a current of 0.20 amperes is passed through an electrolytic cell for 60 minutes
questions.explanation: Quantity of electricity Q = I × t. Q = 0.20 A × (60 × 60) seconds = 720 Coulombs.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Oxochlorate (I) acid is used as a bleaching agent because it is
questions.explanation: Oxochlorate (I) acid (HOCl) releases nascent oxygen, which acts as a powerful oxidizing agent to bleach dyes.

questions.instruction: Determine the IUPAC name.
questions.question: The IUPAC name for CH₃CH(CH₃)CHClCH(CH₃)CH₃ is
questions.explanation: The longest chain has 5 carbons (pentane). Numbering from either side puts methyl at 2,4 and chloro at 3. Name: 3-chloro-2,4-dimethylpentane. (Note: Option D in original text corrected to match structure logic).

questions.instruction: Identify the gas properties.
questions.question: A colourless gas with a pungent smell is evolved when dilute hydrochloric acid is added to a sample of a salt. The gas evolved could turn
questions.explanation: The gas is likely SO2 (from a sulphite). SO2 is a reducing agent that decolorizes acidified purple KMnO4 solution.

questions.instruction: Select the condition for the fastest rate.
questions.question: If 5.0g of marble reacts with 25.0 cm³ hydrochloric acid, which combination has the fastest reaction rate?

options.label: a
options.text: Marble chips and 2.0 mol dm⁻³ HCl(aq)

options.label: b
options.text: Marble chips and 2.5 mol dm⁻³ HCl(aq)

options.label: c
options.text: Powdered marble and 2.5 mol dm⁻³ HCl(aq)

options.label: d
options.text: Powdered marble and 2.0 mol dm⁻³ HCl(aq)

questions.explanation: Reaction rate increases with surface area (powdered marble) and concentration (2.5 mol dm⁻³ HCl).

questions.instruction: Identify the temperature effect.
questions.question: Increasing the temperature generally

options.label: a
options.text: Decreases the solubility of a solid in a liquid but increases the solubility of a gas in a liquid

options.label: b
options.text: Increases the solubility of a solid in a liquid but decreases the solubility of a gas in a liquid

options.label: c
options.text: Increases the solubility of both a solid and a gas in a liquid

options.label: d
options.text: Decreases the solubility of both a solid and a gas in a liquid

questions.explanation: Solubility of most solids increases with temperature (endothermic dissolution), while gas solubility decreases as kinetic energy allows gas molecules to escape the liquid.

questions.instruction: Identify the salt ion.
questions.question: A white precipitate was formed when BaCl₂(aq) was added to an aqueous solution of salt X. The precipitate dissolved in dilute HCl with rapid effervescence. Salt X is likely to contain
questions.explanation: Barium carbonate (BaCO3) is a white precipitate that reacts with HCl to produce CO2 gas (effervescence), whereas BaSO4 would not dissolve in HCl.

questions.instruction: Select the correct option.
questions.question: Before a reaction could take place, there should be
questions.explanation: Chemical reactions involve the breaking of existing bonds in reactant molecules (requiring activation energy) and the formation of new bonds in products.

questions.instruction: Identify the role of SiO2.
questions.question: In the reaction CaO + SiO₂ → CaSiO₃, silicon (IV) oxide is acting as
questions.explanation: SiO2 is an acidic oxide because it reacts with a basic oxide (CaO) to form a salt (CaSiO3).

questions.instruction: Identify the acid type.
questions.question: Which of the following acids would form normal salt only?
questions.explanation: Trioxonitrate (V) acid (HNO3) is monobasic and has only one replaceable hydrogen atom, so it can only form normal salts.

questions.instruction: Calculate the partial pressure.
questions.question: What is the partial pressure of oxygen at s.t.p in a gaseous mixture containing 100 cm³ of oxygen and 900 cm³ of other gases?
questions.explanation: Total volume = 100 + 900 = 1000 cm³. Mole fraction of O2 = 100/1000 = 0.1. Partial pressure = 0.1 × 1.0 atm (stp pressure) = 0.1 atm.

questions.instruction: Identify the property reason.
questions.question: Graphite is used as a dry lubricant due to the presence of
questions.explanation: Graphite has a layered hexagonal structure held together by weak Van der Waals forces, allowing the layers to slide over each other.

questions.instruction: Identify the alkaline gas.
questions.question: Which of the following gases is alkaline?
questions.explanation: Ammonia (NH3) is the only common gas that is alkaline (basic); it turns damp red litmus paper blue.

questions.instruction: Select the correct statement.
questions.question: Which of the following statements about an equilibrium system is correct?
